text: It can be pretty hard to catalog/quantify morale-affecting issues from the individual contributor perspective, simply because the kinds of things you could typically quantify (e.g. number of complaints to management/HR, contributing factors to attrition described in exit interviews, etc) you wouldn't be directly privy to.  And cataloging issues like "interrupted Susan during a meeting" or "had a condescending tone" can simultaneously be true, devastating, and also inspiring of "I'm not sure what to do with this subjective account" from upper management.  Ideally, you could tie it to outcomes (e.g. "derailed meeting and we had to reconvene the next day, wasting everyone's time.")

text: One thing that you could consider, if it were true, would be to ask your manager if there's a plan in place for attrition in your group, and mention that your concerned this person's hire would create that outcome.  The threat of having to open job reqs and backfill definitely gets management's attention.  But I would only go this route if it's a _genuine_ concern.

genuine
concern.

text: You could also consider a different soft approach of something like, "I totally understand if this isn't possible, but is there any way to minimize the amount of collaboration I have to do with {X}?"  You're spending a little political capital here, but it's an honest request, makes this person an inarguable staffing issue, and is hard to argue with, since you're expressing personal feelings on the matter.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Hello everyone! I'm at the point in my career where I am analyzing whether or not I want to stay in independent contributor roles, or move into the people management realm. Annual reviews are coming up and my manager wants to discuss which route I'd like to take.

I love team collaboration and I've always valued myself for being one of the "leading from the back" types of people (i.e. stepping up and taking on responsibilities/overflow work, running trainings, etc.), so early in my career I set my sights on people management. But during the pandemic I was an interim director at an agency and had a bad experience. It's not clear to me whether the experience was negative due to the circumstances (agency life, lack of training, bad manager and pandemic problems) or due to my dislike of people management. I ended up leaving that management role to go back to being an IC in-house, but now my manager is encouraging me to think about people management again.

So my question is: How did you decide whether to stay IC or move into people management?  How did you know you were ready to start managing people?"

One factor I've thought about: how much of the _doing_ do you enjoy?

For me, I love the act of writing itself. Almost any form. I geek out about how emotions translates into text and vice versa, I enjoy etymology, I consider words to be my tools.

I love the doing.

People management means way less _doing_, if you're doing people management properly. The people you manage do most of the doing, and you support their success.

Of course, this isn't black and white any many people managers will find themselves deep in the doing too, for better or for worse... but the distinction is a decent indicator for your lean, IMO.

text:
I'll offer a few quick thoughts:

1. I'm not sure anyone is truly ready to manage people their first time around. But if you have a solid understanding of the work your team is doing and what's involved, it gives you a leg to stand on while you work on your leadership skills.
2. In my marketing leadership experience, most people management role still involve a ton of _doing_ (e.g. strategy and editing). So it's a bit of a false dichotomy to say it's either/or.
3. At 4-7 years into your career, you should still be in the exploration phase until you find what you love doing. I would personally jump at the opportunity to do something new (i.e. the leadership role). It will also be harder to get a first-time leadership role at a new company vs. one you're already in.
Hope that helps!
